sections.1_story_intuition: Computer Awareness covers the basics of computers, their components, and applications. For competitive exams, understanding computer fundamentals, software, hardware, and common terms is essential as questions are frequently asked in the GK section.
2_key_definitions: Computer: An electronic device that processes data.
Hardware: Physical parts of a computer.
Software: Programs and applications that run on a computer.
CPU: Central Processing Unit, the brain of the computer.
RAM: Random Access Memory, temporary storage.
ROM: Read Only Memory, permanent storage.
Input Device: Device used to enter data (e.g., keyboard, mouse).
Output Device: Device that displays results (e.g., monitor, printer).
Operating System: Software that manages hardware and software resources.
Internet: Global network connecting computers worldwide.
3_key_facts_data_points: CPU has ALU, CU, and MU.
MS Windows, Linux, MacOS are operating systems.
Hard disk is a storage device.
Cloud computing: Using remote servers for storage and processing.
Bluetooth: Wireless technology for short-range communication.
Spreadsheet: Software for calculations (e.g., MS Excel).
4_micro_notes: Charles Babbage is the father of computer.
RAM is temporary, ROM is permanent.
5_exam_capsules: Who is the father of computer? Charles Babbage.
What is the first computer? ENIAC.
What is CPU? Central Processing Unit.
What is the full form of URL? Uniform Resource Locator.
What is the full form of TCP/IP? Transmission Control Protocol/Internet Protocol.
What is a virus? Malicious software.
What is a firewall? Network security system.
What is cloud computing? Using remote servers.
What is Bluetooth? Short-range wireless technology.
What is a spreadsheet? Calculation software.
What is the function of printer? Output device.
What is the function of scanner? Input device.
7_traps_confusing_points: Mixing up input and output devices.
Assuming all software is system software.
Mixing up spreadsheet and word processor.
Assuming all operating systems are the same.

8_case_study_context.title: Cloud Computing in Daily Life
8_case_study_context.explanation: Cloud computing allows users to store and access data over the internet instead of local storage. Services like Google Drive and Dropbox are examples, making data accessible from anywhere.
